text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Jordanian press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- King Hussein says Jordan "is a strong fortress which is steadfast in the face of challenges and dangers"; the monarch warns in a visit to the northern city of Irbid of attempts to politicise professional unions and lashes out at those who cast "doubts on the achievements of the nation."
- King Hussein and PLO leader Yasser Arafat discuss the latest peace developments and efforts to get the Middle East peace talks back on track.
- Crown Prince Hassan to visit Washington next week to discuss boosting U.S. economic aid to the kingdom.
- Royal decree appointing Samir Rifai as Speaker of the Senate (the upper house of parliament) after resignation of Ahmed al-Lawzi.
- King says present circumstances necessitate the highest degree of caution; questions the motives of solidarity visits made by opposition leaders to neighbouring Arab capitals.
- Twenty six opposition deputies sign a petition for an extraordinary session of parliament but 41 signatures are needed to constitutionally enable them to get a quorum for a session.
- Israeli opposition leader Ehud Barak to meet King Hussein in Amman on Monday to hold talks on latest peace developments.
- King says Jordan is targetted and lashes out at foreign inspired opposition to his close ties with Israel.
- Crown Prince Hassan discusses creation of an anti-Islamophobia council.
- Irbid masses take to the streets to welcome king and queen; monarch warns against those who "tend to exploit democracy to ruin it, use freedom to spoil it."
- Information minister lists press excerpts in support of new press law.
- Islamic Action Front holds secret balloting to choose candidates for parliamentary elections.
